oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Gegen alles Front machen, was der Demokratie gefährlich werden kann. Ludwig Rosenberg und die Verarbeitung des Nationalsozialismus
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Ahland, Frank
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ludwig Rosenberg
Deutscher Gewerkschaftsbund
Nationalsozialismus
Nachkriegskrise
Biographie
German Trade Unions
National Socialism
Post-War Crisis
Biography
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Driven by the idea of a future democratic socialist Germany, Ludwig Rosenberg (1903–1977), forced into exile in Britain by the National Socialists and later to become chairman of the German Federation of Trade Unions, returns in June 1945 to his destroyed homeland. On the basis of his experience of a functioning democracy and a strong institutionalised worker’s movement gained in exile, he wants to investigate the possibilities of establishing a German equivalent of the Workers’ Educational Association. After six months in post-war Germany, Rosenberg, who lost part of his family to the Nazis, realises that the Nazis were far less successful in instilling their ideology in the minds of the German people than leaving behind a moral indifference and complete ignorance.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Moving the Social; Vol. 35 (2006): Die Gewerkschaftselite der Nachkriegszeit: Prägung - Funktion - Leitbilder; 45-57
